Award.AwardTitle: Matching and Allocation Problems: An Axiomatic Approach with Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for the study of matching and allocation problems with applications to a variety of emerging areas, including applications spurred by the growth of the internet and electronic commerce, as well as non-standard applications such as the design of exchanges for kidney transplants, the assignment of students to schools in districts where there is school choice, etc. Particular attention will be paid to the design of mechanisms in which participants do not benefit from misreporting any private information (such as their preferences) that is relevant to the allocation problem under consideration. These problems will be studied in an axiomatic framework, which seeks to understand mechanisms that satisfy many desirable criteria, whose choice is motivated by the application under consideration. Minimal sets of properties that uniquely determine commonly-used mechanisms will be identified. Further, new mechanisms with compelling efficiency and equity properties will be designed and their use in practice will be evaluated. Several classical flow and matching models---traditionally studied in the operations research literature from the point of view of computational efficiency---will be studied, taking into account incentive constraints and equity objectives.

If successful, the project will result in new mechanisms for several real-life matching and allocation problems. It will also result in the development of new theoretical tools and techniques that may be broadly applicable in understanding the interaction between equity objectives and (both economic and computational) efficiency objectives in the presence of incentive constraints. This award will support the development of a doctoral course focusing on the applications of matching and allocation problems in practice, as well as the redesign of a course that covers O.R. methods in the public sector. The award will also support a graduate student and outreach activities such as the writing of expository articles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research project's focus was on developing an axiomatic approach to matching, assignment and related problems and to use such an approach to select ``good'' mechanisms for practical problems.

Our work has resulted in an improved understanding of various mechanisms for one-sided and two-sided matching problems and has highlighted the role of indifferences in allocating indivisible/divisible goods. For example, in work with D. Saban, we have designed a class of strategyproof and Pareto efficient mechanisms when agents may be indifferent between objects; in work with Chun Ye, we have proved strong impossibility results on assignment problems even on the highly restricted domain of uniform preferences (all agents agree on an ordering of the objects) but may break ties differently; in work with D. Saban, we show how simple computational problems associated with the Random Assignment mechanism (commonly used in many settings) are surprisingly difficult; in work with S. Chandramouli, we have shown that the egalitarian mechanism (proposed in earlier work of Moulin and others) is actually group strategyproof.

While some of the research has unified and generalized results in the literature, other research has focused on formulating new models and developing the associated theory. As an example, in a series of papers with Herve Moulin, we have formulated the bipartite rationing model and have identified compelling mechanisms and rules for solving such models. This model generalizes the classical rationing model to a network setting. In addition to finding good mechanisms/rules, we have managed to obtain an understanding of standard rationing rules that can be extended to the network setting while satisfying some compelling axioms.

Finally, some of the research is motivated by practical considerations and has the potential to impact assignments in practice. As an example, in work with I. Feigenbaum, Y. Kanoria and I. Lo, we have designed a two-round mechanism for (re)allocating students to schools to alleviate the inefficiencies caused by students who drop-out of the school system after the first-round allocation is made. Our mechanism retains much of the strong features of the mechanism currently used. We hope to test the efficacy of this mechanism on real data shortly.

The research undertaken as part of this project was the basis of many PhD dissertations including those of Shyam Chandramouli, Tulia Plumettaz, Daniela Saban, Itai Feigenbaum, Chun Ye, and Irene Lo.
